175.heading: Pining.
175.title: "Dark Valley" 6 p. in Mysterious Stories, no. 5
175.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: A man named Alan hiking in the Scotch highlands is warned by an old shepherd in a kilt not to walk through Dark Valley at night. The hiker goes anyway and is soon frightened by the sound of a bagpipe. After realizing what it is, he finds a house and joins a birthday party for a young woman named Jean. They fall in love, but then he notices that none of the partiers is visible in a mirror. The shepherd shows up in the morning and explains that exactly fifty years earlier a forest fire destroyed the house during a birthday party. Alan grows old sitting in Dark Valley, pining for Jean.

176.heading: Pining.
176.title: "Take Back Those Words"
176.author: by Ken W
176.appears_in: Fitch ; Jayson. 6 p. in True-to-Life Romances, no. 15 (Jan. 1953).
notes: Summary (by Ryan Claytor): Toni is engaged to Dan, a G.I. stationed in Korea, and writes him letters affirming her love while she secretly dates other men. Eventually she falls in love with Roger, one of her suitors, and agrees to marry him. Toni mails Dan one final letter breaking off their engagement and telling the truth about Roger. Then Toni has a startling realization that she only loves Roger because he reminds her of Dan, and breaks up with Roger. Lonely and grief-stricken, Toni pines for Dan until one day he shows up at the door, blind from war wounds. He has the letter in his hand, but he could not read it.

177.title: "Pining Away for Kudzu Dubose"
177.author: Marlette.
notes: Summary: Ida Mae Wombat reads her essay about her Summer vacation, which included computer camp, selling dental floss door-to-door, rushing the stage when Leonard Nimoy appeared at an sf convention in Atlanta, and writing Kudzu's name in magic markers all over her loose-leaf notebook.

595.heading: Pins.
595.title: "The Fatal Point"
595.author: by Andréas ; lettering by David Jackson
595.appears_in: p. 26-34 in Cheval Noir, no. 2 (Oct. 1989) ; collected in the album Fragments (New York: Nantier Beall Minoustchine, 1990).
notes: Summary: In a forest north of Wheatley-End, under the two oldest trees, known as the "Devil's Horns," a wizard named Adam Niels has built a hut. Adam has figured out how to make any sphere self-destruct by sticking a pin in a certain point on it, and has further determined that his hut is on the Earth's destruct point. Whenever he tries his procedure, spheres for miles around break in sympathy, and the villagers are sick of losing lamps. The villagers go to the hut intent on destroying it, and Adam worries what might happen. Just then a gigantic pin from outer space pokes a hole through the hut into the ground, but nothing else happens.

702.title: Pinocchia
notes: Pinocchia / Gibrat, Leroi ; initial concept, Jean-Luc Fromental. -- New York : Nantier Beall Minoustchine, 1996. -- 54 p. : col. ill. ; 30 cm. -- (Eurotica) -- "For adults only." -- Adapted from the story of Pinocchio. -- Call no.: PN6747.G37P5 1996

Summary: Old Galipetto the toymaker is lonely at night, and his face in the mirror instructs him in carving a beautiful wooden woman. He then animates her with lovemaking, and calls her Pinocchia. She calls him Papa, which causes a problem because soon he's in jail for abusing his daughter. Left alone, Pinocchia is picked up by a rich playboy named Lorenzo, who is already surrounded with beautiful women. Two unsavory and bumbling pimps, Renard and Catho, spot Pinocchia as a possible recruit, and they trick her away into a life of sin and pain, for one night anyhow. She returns to Lorenzo, who takes her in, but she starts to get too intense for him. Meanwhile Galipetto has been kicked out of jail and gets a job as gardner on Lorenzo's estate. Other staff members try to give Galipetto a bath, and he runs in terror, stumbling into Pinocchia's room, where she has reverted to wooden form. They are discovered while he is reanimating her. The police are called, and Galipetto runs for it. Trying to follow her Papa, Pinocchia is picked up by Renard and Catho again. This time they enroll her in a traveling sex carnival for awhile. During this time Pinocchia learns that her breasts grow larger if she tells a lie, and that only whipping will bring them back down to size. Renard and Catho then then fly her to the middle of the ocean in a helicopter and dump her, all tied up. A whale swallows her. The whale is a surplus Russian nuclear submarine used as a floating whorehouse by American billionaires. It turns out that Galipetto is a handyman aboard the sub, and he's happy there and doesn't want to leave. Pinocchia jumps overboard alone, tells a little lie to activate her flotation devices, and makes it to shore. Lorenzo finds her on the beach and is persuaded to whip her for awhile to adjust her size. That night Galipetto, who has changed his mind, rows ashore. Lorenzo asks for her hand in marriage, but before the agreement is made Pinocchia wants to try to become a real woman. They return to the workshop and ask the mirror, which reluctantly agrees to help. Pinocchia has to sit on the workbench all night while the mirror thinks about it. Renard and Catho see her through the window, but she's no longer so gullible and greets them with a hatchet. The heavens come to her rescue in the form of a ball of energy, which turns the pimps to puppets and Pinocchia to a real woman. Nine months later a little wooden boy is born.

This summary is from European Comics in English Translation (Jefferson, NC : McFarland & Company, 2002). Used with permission.
